text.p: Here are highlights of stories reported by Hungary's press, based on information by Nepszabadsag's Hungary Around the Clock service. For further details on how to subscribe to Hungary Around the Clock, please contact Monica Kovacs at (361) 351 7142 or fax your request to (361) 351 7141.
ALL PAPERS
- Prime Minister Gyula Horn and Free Democrat president Ivan Peto testified before the special parliamentary commission investigating the Tocsik affair. @

- A referendum on NATO membership could take place in 1998-1999, following the completion of accession talks, Prime Minister Gyula Horn said. He noted that all documents prove that the allocation of the party headquarters to the Democratic Forum and the Young Democrats was in contravention of the law.

- Some 400-500 workers from the meat company Szekszard Husipari held a demonstration outside Parliament yesterday to protest against what they claimed were arbitrary decisions by the company's German owner. @
- Industry Minister Szabolcs Fazakas said the government is striving to end the international dispute over Hungarian agriculture export subsidies.

- Defence Minister Gyorgy Keleti and his visiting Romanian counterpart Victor Babiuc signed an intergovernmental secrecy protection agreement Monday in Debrecen and also agreed to set up a 200-member joint peacekeeping corps.
- An anticipated foreign trade deficit of $3 billion by year's end will not jeopardize the economy, said Industry Minister Szabolcs Fazakas. @
- The cabinet is launching a new program to help small and medium size enterprises, Finance Ministry officials announced.
- The pharmaceutical company Egis reported pre-tax profits of HUF 5.5 billion on net sales of HUF 24.68 billion last year.
- The Zalaegerszeg-based refrigeration company Goldsun is expected to be offered for sale in a week.
NEPSZABADSAG
- Christian Democrat vice-president Miklos Gaspar said that eight signatures required to submit a no-confidence motion against caucus leader Tamas Isepy have been collected. @
- The Russian state arms agency, Roszvooruyhenie is reportedly offering three types of planes that fully conform to NATO standards.
VILAGGAZDASAG
- Prime Minister Gyula Horn begins a two-day official visit to Norway today.
- The National Bank of Hungary reduced its repo rates by 0.5 percent on Monday.
- Some 2.5-3 million people, 25 percent of the population, live below the subsistence level in Hungary, according to a Central Statistics Office report. @
- The OTP Group closed last year with consolidated after-tax profits up nearly 50 percent to HUF 10.3 billion.
- The salami maker Pick Rt. reported a pre-tax profit of HUF 2.44 billion last year, 28.2 percent up on a year earlier.
- The preliminary balance sheet of the Fotex group shows after-tax profits of HUF 511 million and profit from trading of HUF 1.05 billion on sales of HUF 37.1 billion.
MAGYAR HIRLAP
- The Hungarian Oil and Gas Co. MOL has requested the Hungarian Energy Office to review gas prices.
